questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Interleukins

Role

IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells

IL-5

Development and activation of eosinophils→ Recruited to the site of allergen exposure→ Release inflammatory mediators and enzymes→ Tissue damage and inflammation

IL-13
  • Amplifies IgE production
  • Acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion

IL-10
  • Anti-inflammatory cytokine
  • Inhibits cytokine production by Th1 cells and macrophages.

questions.text: A Rh-negative mother delivered an Rh-positive baby, and Coomb’s test was positive for the baby. What is the mechanism of hypersensitivity seen in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Opsonisation and Phagocytosis

IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn.

Complement activation

and inflammation
  • Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation rather than phagocytosis or cell lysis.
  • The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, attracting neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors.
  • Activated leukocytes release enzymes, causing tissue damage.
  • Goodpasture syndrome.
  • Acute rheumatic fever.

Antibody-dependent

cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
 

Natural killer cells bind to antibody-antigen complexes, inducing apoptotic cell death.
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Insulin resistant diabetes

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic)

Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis).
  • Graves disease
  • Myasthenia gravis

Mnemonic: My Blood Group Is Rh Positive

My

Myasthenia Gravis

Blood

Blood transfusion reaction

Group

Good pasture syndrome,

Graves disease

Is

Immune hemolytic anaemia,

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

R

Rh incompatibility,

Rheumatic fever

H

Hyperacute transplant rejection

Positive

Pemphigus (Bullous),

Pernicious Anemia

Type II hypersensitivity (Antibody-mediated)

Opsonisation and complement activation→Phagocytosis

Transfusion reaction, erythroblastosis fetalis, AIHA, ITP.

Complement, Fc receptor-mediated →Inflammation.

Goodpasture syndrome, Acute Rheumatic fever, vascular rejections, vasculitis.

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunctions.

Myasthenia gravis, Pemphigus Vulgaris, Graves disease, Pernicious Anemia, Insulin-resistant diabetes, Hemolytic disease of the newborn.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2?

A 24-year-old female patient presented with a malar rash, recurrent oral ulcers, and multiple joint pains. She has a relevant past history and does not take any medication. Upon further investigations, thrombocytopenia was seen, and the anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibody was positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Marker/Antibody

Clinical Significance

Anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (<30% of patients)

Anti-dsDNA antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (60-70% of patients); correlates with the disease

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)

Highly sensitive but not specific for SLE

Anti-Ro (SSA) and Anti-La (SSB) antibodies

Found in SLE and Sjögren syndrome; associated with neonatal lupus

Anti-ribosomal-P antibodies

Specific for neuropsychiatric manifestations in SLE

Anti-histone antibodies

Seen in drug-induced lupus; less specific for SLE

Complements C3 and C4

Low levels indicate complement consumption and disease activity

questions.text: Xenograft is:
questions.explanation:
Type of Graft

Description

Autograft

An organ or tissue is taken from an individual and grafted on him/ herself

(Option C ruled out)

Isograft

Grafts between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins

(Option D ruled out)

Allograft

Graft between two genetically non-identical members of the same species (e.g. organ transplants between two non-identical and compatible individuals. (Option B ruled out)

Xenograft

Graft from one species to another (e.g., pig skin is a temporary substitute for burn treatment). (Option A)

Synthetic Graft

Artificial materials or bioengineered constructs replace or support damaged tissue (e.g., artificial skin substitutes, bone graft substitutes).

questions.text: A child, upon disturbing a bee hive, had several stings. After a few minutes, the child developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. Which of the following is the principal mediator of this reaction?
questions.explanation:
Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF).

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin).

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach

Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock.

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male presents with fatigue, breathlessness, and palpitations. On examination, he has pedal oedema, with a pulse rate of 55 bpm, BP of 100/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. ECG is normal, and echocardiography reveals restrictive cardiomyopathy. A cardiac biopsy stained with Congo red shows apple-green birefringence under polarised light. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type of Amyloidosis

Amyloid Protein

Associated Conditions

Primary Amyloidosis (AL)

Amyloid Light Chain (AL)

Plasma cell disorders (e.g., multiple myeloma)

Secondary Amyloidosis (AA)

Amyloid-Associated (AA)

Chronic inflammation (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, IBD)

Hereditary Amyloidosis

Transthyretin (TTR)

Familial amyloid polyneuropathies (e.g., familial Mediterranean fever)

Hemodialysis-Associated

β2-Microglobulin

Long-term hemodialysis

Senile Systemic Amyloidosis

Transthyretin (TTR)

Ageing, mutations in TTR

Localised Amyloidosis

Varies (often AL type)

Specific organs (e.g., tongue, lung, skin, bladder)

Endocrine Amyloidosis

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (Acal)

Endocrine tumours (e.g., medullary thyroid carcinoma, pancreatic islet tumours)

questions.text: Which of the following mediators is involved in the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity? Mast cell Histamine Neutrophils Prostaglandins Leukotrienes
questions.explanation:
Mast cells

Histamine

Prostaglandins

Leukotrienes

Primary effector cells.

Activated by allergens cross-linking with IgE antibodies.

Released by mast cells.

Causes vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, and mucus production.

They are lipid mediators released by mast cells.

Contribute to vasodilation, vascular permeability, and bronchoconstriction.

A group of lipid mediators released by mast cells.

Promote bronchoconstriction, increased vascular permeability, and the recruitment of other inflammatory cells.

 

Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF). 

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin)

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach

Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to an increase in which immunoglobulin?
Isotype switching is seen in:
questions.explanation:
IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD by his parents with complaints of recurrent infections. On mediastinal imaging, the thymus gland was found to be absent. Based on further investigation, ADA levels are low. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Severe combined immu

XLR ( X-linked recessive variety)

 

AR ( Autosomal recessive variety)
  • Most common
  • Defect in the gamma subunit of cytokine receptors: IL2, IL4, IL7, Il15.
  • IL 2 and IL 15: Defective NK cells
  • IL 4: No antibody production
  • IL 7: Defective T-cell development
  • B cells function normally.

There are three types of AR :

  • Adenosine deaminase deficiency (most common): Involves all cells (B cells, T cells, and NK cells)
  • JAK-3 defects: It affects cytokine development. Defective T cells and NK cells. B cells function normally.
  • RAG1 and RAG2 (Recombinant activation gene) defect: This gene is needed to develop B cell and T cell receptors. When this gene is affected, defects in B cells and T cells are observed. NK cells function normally.

questions.text: A graft from an identical twin is called:
questions.explanation:
Type of Graft

Description

Autograft (Option B)

An organ or tissue is taken from an individual and grafted on him/ herself.

Isograft

Grafts between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins

Allograft (Option A)

Graft between two genetically non-identical members of the same species (e.g. organ transplants between two non-identical and compatible individuals.

Xenograft (Option D)

Graft from one species to another (e.g., pig skin is a temporary substitute for burn treatment).

Synthetic Graft

Artificial materials or bioengineered constructs replace or support damaged tissue (e.g., artificial skin substitutes, bone graft substitutes).

questions.text: Graft from an identical twin is called:
questions.explanation:
Type of Graft

Description

Autograft

An organ or tissue is taken from an individual and grafted on him/ herself

(Option B ruled out)

Isograft

Grafts between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins

(Option C)

Allograft

Graft between two genetically non-identical members of the same species (e.g. organ transplants between two non-identical and compatible individuals. (Option A ruled out)

Xenograft

Graft from one species to another (e.g., pig skin is a temporary substitute for burn treatment). (Option D ruled out)

Synthetic Graft

questions.text: A teenager developed swelling of the face, lips, and tongue and also found it difficult to breathe within a few minutes of consuming prawns. What type of hypersensitivity is seen here?
questions.explanation:
Type

Mechanism

Immune Components

Features

Examples

Type I: Immediate

(Option A)

IgE-mediated degranulation of mast cells and basophils after allergen binding.
  • IgE antibodies
  • Mast cells
  • Histamine
  • Rapid onset (minutes)
  • Localised or systemic reactions
  • Mediated by histamine.
  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • Asthma
  • Urticaria (hives)
  • Food allergies

Type II: Cytotoxic

(Option B ruled out)

Antibody-mediated destruction or dysfunction of target cells.
  • IgG, IgM antibodies
  • Complement
  • Phagocytes
  • Targets specific cells or tissues.
  • Cell lysis or dysfunction.
  • Involves complement activation.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Graves' disease

Type III: Immune Complex

(Option C ruled out)

Deposition of immune complexes in tissues, leading to inflammation and damage.
  • IgG, IgM Antibodies
  • Complement
  • Neutrophils
  • Immune complex deposition in vessels.
  • Tissue inflammation and damage (vasculitis).
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Serum sickness

Type IV: Delayed

(Option D ruled out)

T-cell-mediated immune response, leading to inflammation and tissue damage.
  • T cells (CD4+, CD8+)
  • Macrophages
  • Delayed onset (48–72 hours).
  • Involves cytokine release and macrophage recruitment.
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Tuberculin skin test (PPD)
  • Granulomatous inflammation (e.g., tuberculosis)

questions.text: Which type of cells are implicated in the development of contact dermatitis in a 12-year-old boy who presented to the emergency department?
questions.explanation:
Mechanisms of Type IV hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Cytokine-mediated inflammation
(mediated by CD4+ T cells)
  • CD4+ T cells recognise protein antigens presented by APCs and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells.
  • Th1 cells secrete cytokines like IFN-γ, activating macrophages to cause tissue damage and fibrosis.
  • Th17 cells produce IL-17 to recruit neutrophils, promoting inflammation.
  • Tuberculin test (a classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity)
  • Granulomas
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • IBD
  • Psoriasis

T cell-mediated cytotoxicity (mediated by CD8+ T cells)

 

 
  • Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill antigen-bearing target cells, including tumour cells, virus-infected cells, and allogeneic tissue, during graft rejection.
  • CTLs use perforin-granzyme-dependent killing and Fas-Fas ligand-dependent killing mechanisms to induce apoptosis in target cells.
  • Type 1 DM
  • Hepatic injury in HBV infection
  • Graft vs host disease

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis Jiroveci pneumonia. The flowcytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes 3 and 4) is shown below (Boxes 1 and 2 are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct option C: Hyper IgM

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is a type 2 lepra reaction?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Type III hypersensitiv

questions.text: Which of the following organs is a primary lymphoid organ?
questions.explanation:
Primary Lymphoid Organs

Secondary Lymphoid Organs

Bone Marrow:

  • Origin of all blood cells from pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells (a process called hematopoiesis).
  • Hematopoiesis shifts to bone marrow from the liver after fetal life, eventually confined to axial bones after puberty.
  • Progenitor T and B cells develop in bone marrow; B cells mature here, while T cell progenitors migrate to the thymus.

Lymph Nodes: (Option A ruled out)

  • Filter antigens and activate T and B cells.
  • Structured into cortex (B cell area), paracortex (T cell area), and medulla (rich in plasma cells).

Spleen: (Option B ruled out)

  • Largest secondary lymphoid organ, involved in filtering blood-borne antigens.
  • Contains white pulp (T and B cells) and red pulp (site of RBC destruction).

Thymus: (Option C)

  • Site of T cell proliferation and maturation.
  • Developed from the third/fourth pharyngeal pouch in embryonic life.
  • Active during childhood, decreases in size after puberty.
  • Thymic hormones (e.g., thymulin, thymopoietin) help attract and mature T cells.
  • Central tolerance occurs here, removing self-reactive T cells to prevent autoimmunity.

Mucosa-associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT): (Option D ruled out)

  • Located in mucosal sites (intestine, respiratory, urogenital tracts) to protect against pathogens.
  • Includes loose clusters of lymphoid cells and organised structures (e.g., tonsils, Peyer’s patches in intestines).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydrorhodamine test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings?
The below-given ANA pattern on immunofluorescence (IF) is seen; identify the pattern.
questions.explanation:
Homogeneous or diffuse staining of nuclei

(Option D ruled out)
  • Antibodies reactive with dsDNA, nucleosomes, and histones,
  • This is seen in SLE,
    • Drug-induced lupus
    • Mixed connective tissue disorder

Speckled pattern

(Option B ruled out)

 
  • Antibodies against various nuclear antigens, including Sm and RNPs
  • It is seen in SLE
    • Scleroderma
    • Sjogren’s syndrome

Nucleolar pattern

(Option A ruled out)
  • Antibodies against nucleolar proteins.
  • It is seen in Scleroderma and Polymyositis.

Anti-centromere antibodies

(Option C)

Systemic sclerosis, Sjögren syndrome, and other diseases

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is specific for scleroderma?
questions.explanation:
Diffuse & Limited Systemic Sclerosis

Features

Diffuse

Limited

Skin involvement

Proximal & Distal extremities, face, trunk

Distal to elbows, face

Raynaud’s Phenomenon

Onset <1 year/at the time of skin changes

Precede skin diseases by years

Organ Involvement

Pulmonary (Interstitial fibrosis),

Renal (Renovascular hypertensive crisis),

GI & Cardiac

GI, Biliary cirrhosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension

Nail fold capillaries

Dilatation and dropout

Dilatation without significant dropout

Antinuclear antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase 1

Anticentromere

Antibodies

Conditions

Anti-La antibody (Option B)

Sjogren’s syndrome

Anti-Jo-1 antibody (Option C)

Dermatomyositis

Anti-U1 RNP antibodies (Option D)

Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)

Antibodies

Conditions

Anti-topoisomerase 1 antibody

Diffuse Systemic Sclerosis

Anticentromere antibody

Limited Systemic Sclerosis

Anti-La antibody

Sjogren’s syndrome

Anti-Jo-1 antibody

Dermatomyositis

Anti-U1 RNP antibodies

Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)

questions.text: Which of the following genes is responsible for the regulation of T lymphocytes by the thymus?
What does CD40 deficiency in a person signify?
After class switching, a particular class of antibody is produced, but IgM and IgD are expressed concomitantly on the surface of a B cell due to which of the following phenomena?
What method is employed for the detection of autoantibodies?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Limitation

Direct Immunofluorescence

 

Detects antigen directly using a fluorescent-labelled antibody.

(Option A ruled out)

Requires separate fluorescent conjugates for each antigen.

Indirect Immunofluorescence

It uses antiglobulin fluorescent conjugate to detect human antibodies, enhancing versatility.

Allows the use of a single anti-human conjugate.

questions.text: A young person with recurrent seasonal conjunctivitis presents with itchiness and eye-watering. What is the most likely cell involved in the immediate phase of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Type I hypersensitivity reaction phases and its features

Phase

Timing

Mechanism

Immediate Phase

Seconds to minutes

Mast cell/basophil degranulation: IgE cross-linking leads to the release of histamine and other mediators.

Late Phase

4-12 hours, peaks at 24-48 hours, lasting up to days

Inflammatory cell recruitment: Cytokines/chemokines attract eosinophils, neutrophils, and macrophages, causing sustained inflammation. (Options A & C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
Rheumatoid arthritis

Epidemiology

  • Male to female ratio - 1:3.
  • Peaks between 25 and 55 years.
  • Remains constant between 55 and 75.

Genetics

  • Strongly associated with the HLA-DRβ1 gene.
  • Higher concordance in monozygotic twins.

Triggers and suppressors

  • Cigarette smoking and infections can trigger RA in genetically predisposed individuals by citrullination of proteins.
  • RA may remit during pregnancy and can first appear postpartum due to immune suppression and hormonal changes.

Pathogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of natural killer cells?

A boy presents with recurrent episodes of melena. On examination, there is eczema of the skin with multiple petechiae. His platelet count is low, with normal RBC and WBC counts. Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation for this patient?

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of innate immunity?
questions.explanation:
Difference between innate and acquired immunity

Innate/native immunity

Acquired/adaptive immunity

Present since birth.

Occurs after exposure to the pathogen.

Quick, non-specific response.

Slower, specific response to a pathogen.

No immunological memory.

Has immunological memory.

Examples include:

  • Epithelial barriers like skin, GIT.
  • Plasma proteins like C-reactive protein.
  • Neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, complement system.

Cells are of 2 types:

  • B lymphocytes: Provides humoral immunity and produces antibodies.
  • T lymphocytes: Involved in cell-mediated immunity and help with immunity against intracellular microbes.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not involved in the Th1 response?
questions.explanation:
Subtype

Function and Characteristics

Key Cytokines

TH1
  • Involved in chronic inflammatory diseases.
  • Activated by IL-12 (Option C) from APCs.
  • Secrete IFN-gamma, activating macrophages.
  • Stimulates macrophages to form epithelioid cells and giant cells.

IFN-gamma

(Option A)

IL-2

(Option B)

TH2
  • Responsible for the alternative pathway of macrophage activation.
  • Release cytokines IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13.
  • To expel parasites from the body, stimulate eosinophil activation, antibody production (especially IgE), and mucus production.

IL-4, IL-5, IL-13

TH17
  • Defend against extracellular bacteria and fungi.
  • Secrete IL-17 and IL-22, attracting neutrophils and monocytes.

IL-17, IL-22

Treg

(T regulatory)
  • It suppresses immune response and maintains homeostasis and self-tolerance.
  • Inhibit T cell proliferation and cytokine production, preventing autoimmune reaction.

IL-10, TGF-beta

Tfh (Follicular T helper)
  • Assist B cells in rapid proliferation and antibody production.
  • Help produce antibodies with greater affinity.

IL-21

questions.text: Xenograft is:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Graft across species:

Graft types Description Examples
Autograft Transfer of tissue from one site to another in the same individual Skin grafts from one site to another on the same individual
Allograft Transfer of tissue between genetically non-identical individuals of the same species Kidney transplant from a living or deceased donor
Isograft Transfer of tissue between genetically identical individuals (e.g., identical twins) Organ transplant between monozygotic twins
Xenograft Transfer of tissue between different species Pig heart valve transplant in a human

Graft types Description Examples
Autograft Transfer of tissue from one site to another in the same individual Skin grafts from one site to another on the same individual
Allograft Transfer of tissue between genetically non-identical individuals of the same species Kidney transplant from a living or deceased donor
Isograft Transfer of tissue between genetically identical individuals (e.g., identical twins) Organ transplant between monozygotic twins
Xenograft Transfer of tissue between different species Pig heart valve transplant in a human

questions.text: What is the single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Allograft Arteriopath

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of severe abdominal pain and headaches for the past two days. He has a history of myalgia and several episodes of vomiting . His parents self-medicated with paracetamol, but the patient had no relief. A dengue NS-1 antigen test was ordered, which came out positive . What is the first line of defence for the body in the given scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Natural K

questions.text: Type II Hypersensitivity is seen in:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Pernicious A

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in SCID?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - BTK

questions.text: Basophils are activated by?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - IL-5

Interleukin Function
IL-1
  • Pro-inflammatory cytokine
  • Stimulates the production of acute-phase proteins
  • Activates T cells and macrophages
IL-2
  • Stimulates the growth and activation of T cells
  • Enhances cytotoxic T cell and NK cell activity
  • Supports B cell differentiation
IL-4
  • Stimulates Th2 cell differentiation
  • Promotes B cell activation and antibody production
  • Enhances class switching to IgE
IL-6
  • Promotes inflammation and acute-phase response
  • Stimulates the production of acute-phase proteins
  • Induces B cell differentiation
IL-10
  • Anti-inflammatory cytokine
  • Suppresses the immune response and inflammation
  • Inhibits antigen-presenting cell function
IL-12
  • Promotes Th1 cell differentiation
  • Activates NK cells and cytotoxic T cells
  • Enhances IFN-γ production
IL-17
  • Promotes inflammation and neutrophil recruitment
  • Involved in host defense against extracellular pathogens

questions.text: Which of the following about γ δ T-cells is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin

options.label: B
options.text: Need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition

questions.correct_answer: B. Need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reactions are all except :
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - IgE

questions.text: Which of the following cells is responsible for graft rejection?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - T

questions.text: The X-ray of a middle-aged man showed multiple lytic lesions , following which a urine examination was done . The sample revealed Bence Jones proteins. Which is the most common immunoglobulin associated with this condition ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - IgG
